artworks.title: Venus of Willendorf
artworks.medium: Oolitic limestone with traces of red ochre pigment
artworks.description: The Venus of Willendorf is an 11.1-centimetre-tall (4.4 in) Upper Paleolithic figurine of a female figure, estimated to have been made between 25,000 and 23,000 BCE. It was discovered in 1908 at a Paleolithic site near Willendorf, a village in Lower Austria, by archaeologist Josef Szombathy. Carved from oolitic limestone not native to the region and tinted with red ochre, the figurine is one of the most famous examples of prehistoric art and is thought to represent fertility or a mother goddess.

artworks.title: Lascaux Cave Paintings
artworks.medium: Mineral pigments (ochre, hematite, manganese oxide) on limestone cave walls
artworks.description: The Lascaux Cave Paintings are a series of Upper Paleolithic parietal artworks found in a cave complex near Montignac, Dordogne, southwestern France. The site contains over 600 paintings and 1,500 engravings, primarily depicting large animals such as aurochs, horses, and deer, which were native to the region at the time. The paintings are renowned for their vivid colors, dynamic compositions, and sophisticated techniques, including the use of mineral pigments and natural contours of the cave walls. The cave was discovered in 1940 and has since become a key reference for understanding prehistoric art and human symbolic behavior.
artworks.creation_location: Lascaux Cave, near Montignac, Dordogne, France

artworks.title: Altamira Cave Paintings
artworks.medium: Mineral pigments (ochre, hematite, charcoal) on limestone cave walls
artworks.description: The Cave of Altamira is a renowned prehistoric site featuring polychrome rock paintings and engravings of bison, horses, deer, wild boar, and human hands. Created by Upper Paleolithic peoples, the cave's artwork is celebrated for its vivid naturalism and sophisticated use of color and shading. Discovered in 1868 near Santillana del Mar, Cantabria, Spain, Altamira is considered one of the most important examples of Paleolithic cave art.

artworks.title: Lion-Man
artworks.description: The Löwenmensch figurine, also called the Lion-man of Hohlenstein-Stadel, is a prehistoric sculpture discovered in 1939 in the Hohlenstein-Stadel cave in the Swabian Jura, Germany. The German name, Löwenmensch, meaning 'lion-person' or 'lion-human', is most frequently used because it was discovered and is exhibited in Germany. It is an anthropomorphic figurine combining a human-like body with the head of a cave lion, and is one of the oldest known examples of figurative art.
artworks.creation_location: Hohlenstein-Stadel cave, Swabian Jura, Baden-Württemberg, Germany

artworks.title: Venus of Brassempouy
artworks.description: The Venus of Brassempouy is a fragmentary ivory figurine from the Upper Palaeolithic, representing one of the earliest known realistic depictions of a human face. Discovered in 1894 in the Grotte du Pape at Brassempouy, France, it is a rare example of prehistoric art showing detailed facial features and stylized hair.

artworks.title: Chauvet Cave Paintings
artworks.medium: Charcoal and ochre pigments on limestone cave walls
artworks.description: The Chauvet-Pont-d'Arc Cave in the Ardèche department of southeastern France contains some of the earliest and best-preserved examples of prehistoric figurative cave art. The paintings depict animals such as horses, rhinoceroses, lions, buffalo, and mammoths, and demonstrate advanced techniques of shading, perspective, and movement. The cave also preserves evidence of Upper Paleolithic human activity.

artworks.title: Stonehenge
artworks.description: Stonehenge is a prehistoric megalithic monument located on Salisbury Plain in Wiltshire, England, approximately two miles (3 km) west of Amesbury. It consists of an outer ring of massive vertical sarsen standing stones, each about 4 meters (13 feet) high, 2.1 meters (7 feet) wide, and weighing around 25 tons, topped by horizontal lintel stones connected using mortise and tenon joints—an engineering feature unique among contemporary monuments. Within the outer circle is a ring of smaller bluestones and a horseshoe arrangement of five free-standing trilithons (pairs of large vertical stones topped with a single lintel). The monument is aligned with the sunrise of the summer solstice and the sunset of the winter solstice. Stonehenge is set within extensive earthworks and is part of a complex landscape rich in Neolithic and Bronze Age monuments, including numerous burial mounds (tumuli).

artworks.title: Newgrange
artworks.medium: Earth, stone, quartz, and other local materials
artworks.description: Newgrange is a prehistoric monument in County Meath, Ireland, situated on a rise overlooking the River Boyne. It is an exceptionally grand passage tomb built during the Neolithic Period, around 3200 BCE, making it older than Stonehenge and the Egyptian pyramids. The monument consists of a large circular mound with an inner stone passageway and chambers. Newgrange is the principal monument in the Brú na Bóinne complex, a UNESCO World Heritage Site that also includes the passage tombs of Knowth and Dowth, as well as other henges, burial mounds, and standing stones.

artworks.title: Hall of the Bulls
artworks.medium: Mineral pigments (ochre, charcoal, manganese oxide) on limestone cave walls
artworks.description: The Hall of the Bulls is the most famous chamber within the Lascaux Cave complex in southwestern France. Its walls are adorned with large-scale polychrome paintings of bulls, horses, stags, and other animals, created during the Upper Paleolithic period. The imagery demonstrates sophisticated use of line, color, and perspective, and is considered a masterpiece of prehistoric art. The paintings are believed to have held ritual or symbolic significance for the people who created them.
artworks.creation_location: Lascaux Cave, near Montignac, Dordogne, France

artworks.title: Venus of Laussel
artworks.medium: Limestone bas-relief with red ochre pigment
artworks.description: The Venus of Laussel is an 18.11-inch-high (46.0-centimetre) limestone bas-relief of a nude female figure, painted with red ochre. Carved into the wall of a rock shelter in Marquay, Dordogne, France, it depicts a woman holding a horn-shaped object. The figure is associated with the Gravettian Upper Paleolithic culture and is one of the most significant examples of prehistoric art.

artworks.title: Chauvet Cave Paintings
artworks.medium: Charcoal and ochre on limestone cave walls
artworks.description: The Chauvet-Pont-d'Arc Cave in the Ardèche department of southeastern France contains some of the oldest and best-preserved figurative cave paintings in the world. These artworks depict animals such as horses, lions, mammoths, and rhinoceroses, and provide insight into the life, beliefs, and artistic abilities of Upper Paleolithic humans.

artworks.title: Cosquer Cave Paintings
artworks.medium: Mineral pigments and charcoal on limestone cave walls; engravings
artworks.description: The Cosquer Cave contains prehistoric parietal art created by Upper Paleolithic humans. Discovered by diver Henri Cosquer in 1985, the cave is now accessible only via a submerged tunnel due to post-glacial sea level rise. The cave walls feature over 500 images, including hand stencils, animal figures such as horses, ibex, bison, seals, and penguins, as well as geometric signs. The artwork dates to both the Gravettian and Solutrean periods, making it a rare example of Paleolithic cave art with unique marine motifs.
artworks.creation_location: Calanque de Morgiou, near Marseille, Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur, France

artworks.title: Pech Merle Cave Paintings
artworks.medium: Mineral pigments (charcoal, ochre, manganese dioxide) on limestone cave walls
artworks.description: The Pech Merle Cave Paintings are a collection of prehistoric murals and engravings located in the Pech Merle cave in Cabrerets, Lot, France. The artworks, which include images of spotted horses, mammoths, bison, human figures, and hand stencils, were created by Upper Paleolithic peoples during the Gravettian and Magdalenian periods. The cave is notable for the exceptional preservation and variety of its parietal art, which spans several millennia.
artworks.creation_location: Pech Merle Cave, Cabrerets, Lot, France

artworks.title: Cave of El Castillo (Hand Stencils)
artworks.medium: Red ochre pigment on limestone cave wall
artworks.description: The Cave of El Castillo contains some of the oldest known cave art in Europe, including a series of red ochre hand stencils and disk shapes. The hand stencils were created by blowing pigment over a hand pressed against the cave wall, leaving a negative impression.
artworks.creation_location: Cueva de El Castillo, Puente Viesgo, Cantabria, Spain

artworks.title: Apollo 11 Cave Stones
artworks.medium: Charcoal, ochre, and white pigment on quartzite slabs
artworks.description: The Apollo 11 Cave Stones are a group of seven quartzite slabs with charcoal and ochre depictions of animals and geometric patterns, discovered in the Apollo 11 Cave in southwestern Namibia. These portable artworks are among the oldest known examples of figurative art in Africa, reflecting the symbolic and artistic capabilities of early modern humans.

artworks.title: Blombos Cave Engraved Ochre
artworks.description: The Blombos Cave Engraved Ochre is a piece of ochre with deliberately engraved geometric patterns, discovered in Blombos Cave on the southern coast of South Africa. The engraved ochre, dating to around 75,000 BCE, is among the earliest known examples of abstract or symbolic art made by Homo sapiens. The site has yielded several pieces of engraved ochre, beads, and other artifacts, providing crucial evidence for the cognitive and cultural development of early humans.
artworks.creation_location: Blombos Cave, Western Cape, South Africa

artworks.title: Diepkloof Rock Shelter Engravings
artworks.description: The Diepkloof Rock Shelter Engravings are a series of geometric patterns incised onto ostrich eggshell fragments, discovered at the Diepkloof Rock Shelter in the Western Cape, South Africa. These engravings are among the earliest known examples of symbolic behavior by early Homo sapiens, suggesting the use of abstract representation and possibly early forms of communication or group identity.
artworks.creation_location: Diepkloof Rock Shelter, Verlorenvlei, Western Cape, South Africa

artworks.title: Tassili n'Ajjer Rock Art
artworks.description: Tassili n'Ajjer is a vast plateau in southeastern Algeria, renowned for its extensive collection of prehistoric rock art. The site features thousands of petroglyphs and paintings depicting animals, human figures, and scenes of daily life, providing invaluable insight into early Saharan cultures and environmental changes over millennia.

artworks.title: Bhimbetka Rock Shelters
artworks.medium: Rock shelters with natural pigments on sandstone
artworks.description: The Bhimbetka rock shelters are a group of prehistoric rock shelters and caves in central India, featuring some of the earliest traces of human life and habitation in the Indian subcontinent. The site contains over 750 shelters, many of which are adorned with ancient rock paintings that span from the Paleolithic and Mesolithic periods through to the historic era. These paintings depict scenes of hunting, dancing, music, and daily life, offering invaluable insight into early human culture and artistic expression.

artworks.title: Sulawesi Cave Paintings
artworks.medium: Mineral pigment on limestone cave walls
artworks.description: The Sulawesi Cave Paintings, found in the Maros-Pangkep karst region of South Sulawesi, Indonesia, are among the oldest known examples of figurative art in the world. These Paleolithic paintings, created by early humans, include hand stencils and depictions of animals such as warty pigs and anoa. Dating techniques have established that some of the artworks are at least 43,900 years old, making them a crucial discovery in the study of prehistoric art and human cognitive development.
artworks.creation_location: Maros-Pangkep karst caves, Maros Regency, South Sulawesi, Indonesia

artworks.title: Leang Tedongnge Pig Painting
artworks.medium: Red ochre pigment on limestone rock wall
artworks.description: The Leang Tedongnge Pig Painting is a prehistoric cave painting depicting a Sulawesi warty pig, discovered in the Leang Tedongnge cave in Maros-Pangkep karst, South Sulawesi, Indonesia. Dated to at least 45,500 years ago, it is currently the oldest known figurative artwork in the world, providing crucial evidence of early human artistic expression.
artworks.creation_location: Leang Tedongnge Cave, Maros Regency, South Sulawesi, Indonesia

artworks.title: Gwion Gwion (Bradshaw) Rock Paintings
artworks.medium: Natural mineral pigments on sandstone rock surfaces
artworks.description: The Gwion Gwion rock paintings, formerly known as Bradshaw paintings, are a major tradition of rock art found in the north-west Kimberley region of Western Australia. These ancient paintings primarily depict finely detailed human figures adorned with elaborate accessories such as headdresses, bags, and tassels. The works are named after Joseph Bradshaw, the first European to record them in 1891, but are known to traditional owners by names such as Gwion Gwion, Kiro Kiro, or Kujon. The exact age and creators of the paintings are debated, but recent studies using radiocarbon dating of overlying wasp nests suggest the oldest figures were painted around 12,000 years ago. The art is deeply significant to local Aboriginal cultures and is the subject of ongoing research and cultural interpretation.

artworks.title: Gwion Gwion Rock Art
artworks.medium: Natural mineral pigments on sandstone rock surfaces
artworks.description: The Gwion Gwion rock paintings, also known as Gwion figures, Kiro Kiro, or Kujon, are one of the two major regional traditions of rock art found in the north-west Kimberley region of Western Australia. These ancient paintings primarily depict finely detailed human figures adorned with accessories such as bags, tassels, and elaborate headdresses. The art is significant to the traditional owners of the land, who have published their own interpretations of the imagery. The identity of the original artists remains unknown, and the age of the art has been debated, though recent studies suggest most figures were created around 12,000 years ago. The site was first recorded by Joseph Bradshaw in 1891, leading to the former name 'Bradshaw paintings.' The art is known by various names in local Indigenous languages, reflecting its cultural importance.

artworks.title: Ubirr Rock Paintings
artworks.medium: Natural mineral pigments on rock surface
artworks.description: The Ubirr Rock Paintings are a collection of ancient Aboriginal rock art located at Ubirr, a prominent rock formation within Kakadu National Park in the Northern Territory of Australia. The site features numerous natural shelters whose walls are covered with paintings created over thousands of years, some dating back at least 20,000 years. The art depicts ancestral beings, human figures, and a rich variety of local fauna including barramundi, catfish, mullet, goannas, turtles, possums, and wallabies. The paintings are renowned for their x-ray style, which shows the internal organs and bone structures of animals.
artworks.creation_location: Ubirr, Kakadu National Park, Northern Territory, Australia

artworks.title: Stonehenge
artworks.description: Stonehenge is a prehistoric megalithic monument located on Salisbury Plain in Wiltshire, England. It consists of a ring of massive standing sarsen stones, each around 4 meters (13 feet) high, 2.1 meters (7 feet) wide, and weighing approximately 25 tons, topped by horizontal lintel stones. Within the outer circle is a ring of smaller bluestones and a horseshoe arrangement of five trilithons. The monument is aligned with the sunrise of the summer solstice and the sunset of the winter solstice, suggesting astronomical and ceremonial significance. Stonehenge is surrounded by earthworks and is part of a larger complex of Neolithic and Bronze Age monuments, including burial mounds.

artworks.title: Newgrange
artworks.medium: Earth, stone (quartz, granite, greywacke, sandstone), corbelled masonry
artworks.description: Newgrange is a prehistoric monument and passage tomb in County Meath, Ireland, constructed during the Neolithic period. The monument consists of a large circular mound with an inner stone passageway and chambers. Its entrance is aligned with the rising sun on the winter solstice, illuminating the inner chamber. Newgrange is the most prominent structure in the Brú na Bóinne UNESCO World Heritage Site, which also includes Knowth and Dowth. The site features megalithic art, including carved spirals and geometric motifs.

artworks.title: Carnac Stones
artworks.description: The Carnac stones are an exceptionally dense collection of megalithic sites near the south coast of Brittany in northwestern France, consisting of stone alignments (rows), dolmens, tumuli, and single menhirs. More than 3,000 prehistoric standing stones were hewn from local granite and erected by the pre-Celtic people of Brittany, forming the largest such collection in the world. Most of the stones are within the Breton municipality of Carnac, but some to the east are within neighboring La Trinité-sur-Mer. The stones were erected at some stage during the Neolithic period, probably around 3300 BCE, but some may date to as early as 4500 BCE.

artworks.title: Göbekli Tepe
artworks.description: Göbekli Tepe is an archaeological site from the Pre-Pottery Neolithic period, located in southeastern Turkey. It consists of a series of monumental circular and oval stone enclosures, featuring massive T-shaped limestone pillars, many of which are carved with reliefs of animals and abstract symbols. The site is considered the world's oldest known monumental architecture, predating Stonehenge by several millennia. Its purpose is believed to have been ritual or religious, providing key insights into early human society, symbolic thought, and the origins of complex social organization.

artworks.title: Ain Ghazal Statues
artworks.description: The Ain Ghazal statues are some of the earliest large-scale human figures ever created, made from lime plaster and reed. Discovered at the Neolithic site of Ain Ghazal near Amman, Jordan, these statues date to the Pre-Pottery Neolithic C period, around 9000 years ago. Archaeologists uncovered 15 full statues and 15 busts in two caches, buried approximately 200 years apart. The statues feature detailed facial features and painted eyes, providing rare insight into early human representation and ritual.

artworks.title: Tower of Jericho
artworks.description: The Tower of Jericho is an 8.5-metre-tall (28 ft) stone structure built during the Pre-Pottery Neolithic A period around 8000 BCE. Located at Tell es-Sultan in the city of Jericho, it is considered one of the oldest monumental stone structures in the world. The tower is part of the earliest known fortified settlement and demonstrates advanced construction techniques for its time. It was discovered and excavated by archaeologist Kathleen Kenyon in the 1950s.

artworks.title: Çatalhöyük Wall Paintings
artworks.description: The Çatalhöyük wall paintings are some of the earliest known examples of large-scale mural art, created by the inhabitants of the Neolithic settlement of Çatalhöyük in southern Anatolia. These paintings depict geometric patterns, hunting scenes, and possibly the earliest known map, reflecting the ritual and daily life of the community. The site, occupied from approximately 7500 to 5600 BCE, provides crucial insight into early urbanization and symbolic expression.
artworks.creation_location: Çatalhöyük, near Küçükköy, Konya Province, Turkey

artworks.title: Neolithic Plastered Skulls
artworks.description: Neolithic Plastered Skulls are human skulls that were modeled with plaster to reconstruct facial features, often with inlaid shells for eyes. These objects were created during the Pre-Pottery Neolithic B period and are among the earliest known examples of portraiture and ancestor veneration. They were typically buried beneath the floors of houses in sites such as Jericho, Ain Ghazal, and Tell Ramad in the ancient Levant.

artworks.title: Mezine Bracelets
artworks.description: The Mezine Bracelets are a set of intricately engraved mammoth ivory bracelets discovered at the Epigravettian site of Mezine, near the Desna River in present-day Chernihiv Oblast, Ukraine. These Paleolithic artifacts are decorated with geometric patterns, including meanders and possible representations of lunar cycles. The site is also notable for yielding the earliest known swastika-like motif. The bracelets demonstrate advanced craftsmanship and symbolic thinking among Upper Paleolithic hunter-gatherers.

artworks.title: Shigir Idol
artworks.description: The Shigir Idol is the world's oldest known wooden sculpture, dating to the early Holocene period. Carved from larch wood, it features geometric motifs and human faces, and is believed to have served ritual or symbolic purposes for Mesolithic hunter-gatherers. The idol provides unique insight into prehistoric art and spirituality.
artworks.creation_location: Shigir peat bog, Ural Mountains, Russia

artworks.title: Magdalenian Reindeer Antler Sculpture
artworks.description: This Magdalenian reindeer antler sculpture is a prehistoric artifact created by Upper Paleolithic peoples in Western Europe. The Magdalenian culture is known for its sophisticated portable art, including intricately carved bone, antler, and ivory objects, often depicting animals. These works provide insight into the symbolic and ritual practices of Ice Age hunter-gatherers.

artworks.title: Bison Licking Insect Bite (La Madeleine)
artworks.description: Bison Licking Insect Bite is a prehistoric carving from the Upper Paleolithic, discovered at Abri de la Madeleine near Tursac in Dordogne, France. This small sculpture, carved from reindeer antler, depicts a bison turning its head to lick a wound or insect bite on its flank. It is a masterful example of Magdalenian portable art, demonstrating both naturalistic observation and technical skill.
artworks.creation_location: Abri de la Madeleine, Dordogne, France

artworks.title: Nazca Geoglyph Precursors
artworks.medium: Earthwork (removal of surface stones to expose lighter soil)
artworks.description: The Nazca geoglyph precursors refer to the earliest large-scale ground drawings in the Nazca Desert of southern Peru, predating the famous Nazca Lines. These geoglyphs were created by ancient pre-Nazca cultures, likely the Paracas and earlier societies, by removing surface stones to reveal lighter soil beneath. The designs include straight lines, geometric shapes, and early animal figures, and they foreshadow the more elaborate Nazca Lines made centuries later. Their purpose remains debated, with theories ranging from ritual pathways to astronomical markers.
artworks.creation_location: Nazca Desert, Ica Region, southern Peru

artworks.title: Paijan Projectile Points
artworks.medium: Knapped stone (chert, quartzite, and other local stones)
artworks.description: Paiján projectile points are distinctive lithic tools associated with the Paiján culture, which flourished on the northern coast of Peru between approximately 13,000 and 10,000 years before present. These elongated, stemmed points were used primarily for hunting and are notable for their fine craftsmanship and adaptation to arid coastal environments. The culture was first identified by Rafael Larco Hoyle in the 1940s and further studied by Claude Chauchat, revealing a network of camps, workshops, and quarries.
artworks.creation_location: Northern coast of Peru (La Libertad and Lambayeque regions)

artworks.title: Monte Verde Artefacts
artworks.description: The Monte Verde artefacts are a collection of stone tools, wooden objects, and other materials discovered at the Monte Verde archaeological site in southern Chile. These artefacts provide evidence of one of the earliest known human settlements in the Americas, predating the Clovis culture by several thousand years.
artworks.creation_location: Monte Verde, Los Lagos Region, Chile

artworks.title: Clovis Points
artworks.medium: Flaked stone (typically chert, flint, jasper, or obsidian)
artworks.description: Clovis points are the characteristically fluted projectile points associated with the New World Clovis culture, a prehistoric Paleo-American culture. They are present in dense concentrations across much of North America and are largely restricted to the north of South America. There are slight differences in points found in the Eastern United States, sometimes leading them to be called "Clovis-like." Clovis points date to the Early Paleoindian period, with all known points dating from roughly 13,400–12,700 years ago. As an example, Clovis remains at the Murray Springs Site date to around 12,900 calendar years ago. Clovis fluted points are named after the city of Clovis, New Mexico, where examples were first found in 1929 by Ridgely Whiteman.
artworks.creation_location: North America (notably near present-day Clovis, New Mexico, and other widespread Paleoindian sites)

artworks.title: Folsom Points
artworks.description: Folsom points are finely crafted projectile points associated with the Folsom tradition of Paleo-Indian North America. Characterized by their distinctive fluting, these stone tools were used primarily as spear points for hunting large game such as Bison antiquus. The first recognized Folsom point was discovered in 1908 at the Folsom site in New Mexico, embedded in the remains of an extinct bison, providing crucial evidence for the antiquity of human presence in the Americas. The points are notable for their advanced flintknapping techniques and are considered a hallmark of early North American lithic technology.
artworks.creation_location: Great Plains region, North America (notably near present-day Folsom, New Mexico, USA)

artworks.title: Poverty Point Earthworks
artworks.description: The Poverty Point Earthworks are a complex series of prehistoric mounds and ridges built by the Poverty Point culture, located in present-day northeastern Louisiana. The site consists of six concentric, semi-elliptical ridges and several large mounds, constructed by a hunter-gatherer society. It is one of the largest and most significant earthwork sites in North America from the Late Archaic period.
artworks.creation_location: West Carroll Parish, northeastern Louisiana, USA

artworks.title: San Rock Paintings
artworks.description: San rock paintings are prehistoric artworks created by the San people, indigenous hunter-gatherers of Southern Africa. These paintings, found in caves and rock shelters, depict humans, animals, hunting scenes, and spiritual figures such as therianthropes (half-human, half-animal beings). The imagery is believed to reflect both daily life and shamanic rituals, including trance dances performed by healers. The art is notable for its dynamic compositions and use of natural pigments.
artworks.creation_location: Drakensberg Mountains, South Africa; Tsodilo Hills, Botswana; Matobo Hills, Zimbabwe; and other sites in Southern Africa

artworks.title: Twyfelfontein Engravings
artworks.description: Twyfelfontein, officially known as ǀUi-ǁAis, is a site of ancient rock engravings located in the Kunene Region of north-western Namibia. The site features thousands of petroglyphs carved into sandstone outcrops, depicting animals, human figures, and abstract patterns. It is one of the largest concentrations of rock art in Africa and provides insight into the spiritual and social lives of early hunter-gatherer communities.

artworks.title: Great Pyramid of Giza
artworks.description: The Great Pyramid of Giza is the largest and most renowned of the Egyptian pyramids. Constructed as the tomb of Pharaoh Khufu (also known as Cheops) during the Fourth Dynasty of the Old Kingdom, it was built over a period of about 20 years. The pyramid is the oldest of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World and the only one to remain largely intact. It is the most prominent monument of the Giza pyramid complex and a UNESCO World Heritage Site, exemplifying the architectural and engineering prowess of ancient Egypt.

artworks.title: Bust of Nefertiti
artworks.description: The Bust of Nefertiti is a painted stucco-coated limestone bust depicting Nefertiti, the Great Royal Wife of the Egyptian pharaoh Akhenaten. Renowned for its exquisite craftsmanship and lifelike depiction, it is considered one of the most iconic images of ancient Egyptian art.

artworks.title: Code of Hammurabi
artworks.medium: Basalt stele inscribed with cuneiform script
artworks.description: The Code of Hammurabi is a Babylonian legal text composed during the reign of Hammurabi, the sixth king of the First Babylonian Dynasty. It is one of the oldest deciphered writings of significant length in the world and consists of 282 laws inscribed on a basalt stele. The text is written in the Old Babylonian dialect of Akkadian and provides insight into the legal, social, and economic structure of ancient Mesopotamia.

artworks.title: Statue of Zeus at Olympia
artworks.medium: Chryselephantine (gold and ivory on a wooden framework)
artworks.description: The Statue of Zeus at Olympia was a monumental seated sculpture of the god Zeus, created by the renowned Greek sculptor Phidias around 435 BCE for the Temple of Zeus at Olympia, Greece. Standing approximately 12.4 meters (41 feet) tall, the statue depicted Zeus enthroned, holding a scepter and a figure of Nike, the goddess of victory. The statue was celebrated for its grandeur and the skillful use of gold and ivory (chryselephantine technique).

artworks.title: Parthenon Sculptures
artworks.description: The Parthenon Sculptures, also known as the Elgin Marbles, are a collection of classical Greek marble sculptures that originally adorned the Parthenon temple on the Acropolis of Athens. They include the pedimental sculptures, metopes, and the frieze, depicting mythological scenes and religious processions in honor of Athena.

artworks.title: Discobolus
artworks.medium: Originally bronze (lost); known through Roman marble copies
artworks.description: The Discobolus by Myron is an ancient Greek sculpture completed at the start of the Classical period, depicting an athlete in the act of throwing a discus. The original bronze is lost, but the work is known through numerous Roman marble copies, such as the Palombara Discobolus. The sculpture is celebrated for its dynamic composition and idealized representation of the athletic male body, capturing a moment of balance and tension.

artworks.title: Venus de Milo
artworks.description: The Venus de Milo, also known as the Aphrodite of Melos, is an ancient Greek marble sculpture representing the goddess Aphrodite (Venus to the Romans). Created during the Hellenistic period, it is celebrated for its beauty, idealized proportions, and enigmatic missing arms. Discovered in 1820 on the island of Milos in the Aegean Sea, the statue has been housed in the Louvre Museum since 1821 and is regarded as one of the most iconic masterpieces of ancient Greek sculpture.

artworks.title: Laocoön and His Sons
artworks.artist: Agesander, Athenodoros, and Polydorus of Rhodes
artworks.description: Laocoön and His Sons, also known as the Laocoön Group, is an ancient marble sculpture depicting the Trojan priest Laocoön and his sons Antiphantes and Thymbraeus being attacked by sea serpents, as described in Virgil's Aeneid. The work is renowned for its intense expression of human agony and its dynamic composition, exemplifying the Hellenistic baroque style. Discovered in Rome in 1506, it has been admired since antiquity and was highly influential during the Renaissance.

artworks.title: Terracotta Army
artworks.description: The Terracotta Army is a vast collection of life-sized terracotta sculptures representing the armies of Qin Shi Huang, the first Emperor of China. The figures include warriors, chariots, and horses, and were buried with the emperor to protect him in the afterlife.

artworks.title: Augustus of Prima Porta
artworks.description: The Augustus of Prima Porta is a full-length marble statue of Augustus Caesar, the first Roman emperor, depicted in military dress and idealized form. It is one of the most iconic images of Roman imperial art.

artworks.title: Hagia Sophia
artworks.artist: Anthemius of Tralles and Isidore of Miletus
artworks.medium: Ashlar and brick masonry with marble, mosaics, and stone inlays
artworks.description: Hagia Sophia, officially the Hagia Sophia Grand Mosque, is a monumental architectural masterpiece in Istanbul, Turkey. Originally constructed as a cathedral by the Eastern Roman (Byzantine) Emperor Justinian I, it was completed in 537 CE and served as the primary church of Constantinople. Renowned for its massive dome, innovative use of pendentives, and richly decorated interiors, it was the world's largest cathedral for nearly a thousand years. Following the Ottoman conquest in 1453, it was converted into a mosque, with minarets and other Islamic features added. In 1935, it became a museum under the Turkish Republic, and in 2020 it was reconverted into a mosque. Hagia Sophia is widely regarded as the epitome of Byzantine architecture and a symbol of the cultural and religious transformations of the region.

artworks.title: Book of Kells
artworks.description: The Book of Kells is an illuminated manuscript Gospel book in Latin, containing the four Gospels of the New Testament along with various prefatory texts and tables. Created by Celtic monks, likely at the monastery of Iona (Scotland) and later at Kells (Ireland), it is renowned for its lavish decoration, intricate interlacing patterns, and vibrant colors. The manuscript is a masterpiece of Insular art and calligraphy, combining Christian iconography with ornate Celtic motifs. The text is mainly from the Vulgate, with some passages from the Vetus Latina.
artworks.creation_location: Iona, Scotland or Kells, County Meath, Ireland

artworks.title: Bayeux Tapestry
artworks.description: The Bayeux Tapestry is an embroidered cloth nearly 70 metres long and 50 centimetres tall that depicts the events leading up to the Norman Conquest of England in 1066, led by William, Duke of Normandy, challenging Harold II, King of England, and culminating in the Battle of Hastings. It is thought to date to the 11th century, within a few years of the battle. Now widely accepted to have been made in England, perhaps as a gift for William, it tells the story from the point of view of the conquering Normans and for centuries has been preserved in Normandy.

artworks.title: Notre-Dame de Paris
artworks.medium: Limestone masonry, wood, lead, stained glass
artworks.description: Notre-Dame de Paris is a renowned medieval Catholic cathedral located on the Île de la Cité in the heart of Paris. An iconic example of French Gothic architecture, it is celebrated for its innovative use of rib vaults, flying buttresses, and its magnificent stained glass rose windows. The cathedral has played a central role in the religious and cultural history of France.

artworks.title: Chartres Cathedral
artworks.description: Chartres Cathedral is a Catholic cathedral in Chartres, France, about 80 km southwest of Paris, and is the seat of the Bishop of Chartres. Dedicated in honour of the Virgin Mary, it was mostly constructed between 1194 and 1220 after a fire destroyed much of the earlier Romanesque structure. The cathedral is renowned for its architectural innovations, extensive sculptural decoration, and its remarkable collection of original 12th- and 13th-century stained glass windows. It stands as one of the best-preserved and most influential examples of High Gothic and Classic Gothic architecture. Its north spire, built in the more ornate Flamboyant style, was added in the early 16th century.

artworks.title: Wilton Diptych
artworks.medium: Tempera on oak panels with gold leaf
artworks.description: The Wilton Diptych is a small portable diptych of two hinged panels, painted on both sides, now in the National Gallery, London. It is an extremely rare survival of a late medieval religious panel painting from England. The diptych was painted for King Richard II of England, who is depicted kneeling before the Virgin and Child in what is known as a donor portrait. He is presented to them by the English saints King Edmund the Martyr, King Edward the Confessor, and his patron saint, John the Baptist. The painting is an outstanding example of the International Gothic style, and the nationality of the unknown artist is probably French or English.

artworks.title: Ghent Altarpiece
artworks.description: The Ghent Altarpiece, also known as the Adoration of the Mystic Lamb, is a monumental and complex polyptych altarpiece created for St Bavo's Cathedral in Ghent, Belgium. Completed in 1432, it is a masterpiece of Early Netherlandish painting, renowned for its intricate iconography, vibrant colors, and pioneering use of oil paints. The work is attributed to the brothers Hubert and Jan van Eyck, with Jan completing the altarpiece after Hubert's death.

artworks.title: Lindisfarne Gospels
artworks.medium: Ink, pigments, and gold on vellum
artworks.description: The Lindisfarne Gospels is an illuminated manuscript gospel book produced in the early 8th century at the monastery of Lindisfarne, off the coast of Northumberland. It is renowned for its intricate decoration and is a masterpiece of Insular art, blending Mediterranean, Anglo-Saxon, and Celtic artistic traditions.

artworks.title: Pietà de Villeneuve-lès-Avignon
artworks.description: The Pietà de Villeneuve-lès-Avignon is a celebrated oil painting by Enguerrand Quarton, depicting the Virgin Mary mourning over the body of Christ, accompanied by Saint John and the donor. Created in the mid-15th century, it is renowned for its emotional intensity, innovative composition, and refined use of color and light, representing a high point of French late medieval painting.

artworks.title: Golden Madonna of Essen
artworks.description: The Golden Madonna of Essen is the oldest known sculpture of the Virgin Mary in Western art. This Romanesque statue depicts the Virgin Mary enthroned and holding the Christ Child. It is constructed with a wooden core covered in thin sheets of gold leaf, and is part of the treasury of Essen Cathedral in Germany. The statue measures 74 centimetres (29 inches) in height and 27 centimetres (10.6 inches) wide at the base.

artworks.title: Mona Lisa
artworks.description: The Mona Lisa is a half-length portrait painting by the Italian artist Leonardo da Vinci. Considered an archetypal masterpiece of the Italian Renaissance, it is renowned for the subject's enigmatic expression, the monumentality of the composition, the subtle modeling of forms, and the atmospheric illusionism. The identity of the sitter is widely believed to be Lisa Gherardini, the wife of Florentine merchant Francesco del Giocondo.

artworks.title: The Last Supper
artworks.description: The Last Supper is a late 15th-century mural painting by Italian artist Leonardo da Vinci, depicting the moment Jesus announces that one of his apostles will betray him. Painted for the refectory of the Convent of Santa Maria delle Grazie in Milan, the work is renowned for its dramatic composition, psychological complexity, and innovative use of perspective.

artworks.title: David
artworks.description: Michelangelo's David is a masterpiece of Renaissance sculpture, depicting the biblical hero David before his battle with Goliath. The statue is renowned for its depiction of human beauty and anatomical precision.

artworks.title: Sistine Chapel Ceiling
artworks.description: The Sistine Chapel ceiling, painted in fresco by Michelangelo between 1508 and 1512, is a monumental work of High Renaissance art depicting scenes from the Book of Genesis and a host of biblical figures, prophets, and sibyls.

artworks.title: The School of Athens
artworks.description: The School of Athens is a renowned fresco by the Italian Renaissance artist Raphael, depicting an idealized gathering of ancient philosophers and scientists. It was painted between 1509 and 1511 as part of the commission to decorate the Stanza della Segnatura, one of the Raphael Rooms in the Apostolic Palace, Vatican City.

artworks.title: The Birth of Venus
artworks.description: The Birth of Venus is a celebrated painting by the Italian Renaissance artist Sandro Botticelli. It depicts the goddess Venus emerging from the sea upon a shell, arriving at the shore as a fully grown woman, symbolizing the birth of beauty and love. The work is renowned for its mythological subject, graceful figures, and flowing composition.

artworks.title: Primavera
artworks.description: Primavera is a large panel painting by Italian Renaissance artist Sandro Botticelli, depicting a group of mythological figures in a garden. It is widely interpreted as an allegory of spring and the fertility of nature, featuring Venus, Cupid, the Three Graces, Mercury, Flora, Chloris, and Zephyrus.

artworks.title: The Arnolfini Portrait
artworks.description: The Arnolfini Portrait is an oil painting on oak panel by the Early Netherlandish painter Jan van Eyck, dated 1434 and now in the National Gallery, London. It is a full-length double portrait, believed to depict the Italian merchant Giovanni di Nicolao Arnolfini and his wife, presumably in their residence at the Flemish city of Bruges.

artworks.title: The Creation of Adam
artworks.description: The Creation of Adam is a fresco painting by Italian Renaissance artist Michelangelo, forming part of the Sistine Chapel's ceiling in Vatican City. Painted circa 1511–1512, it illustrates the Biblical creation narrative from the Book of Genesis in which God gives life to Adam, the first man. The fresco is one of the most iconic images in Western art and is part of a complex scheme of panels depicting episodes from Genesis.

artworks.title: Vitruvian Man
artworks.medium: Pen and ink with wash over metalpoint on paper
artworks.description: Vitruvian Man is a drawing by the Italian Renaissance artist and scientist Leonardo da Vinci, dated to around 1490. Inspired by the writings of the Roman architect Vitruvius, it depicts a nude male figure in two superimposed positions with his arms and legs apart, inscribed within both a circle and a square. The work explores the proportions of the human body and the relationship between art and science, embodying the Renaissance ideal of the unity of knowledge.

artworks.title: The Calling of Saint Matthew
artworks.description: The Calling of Saint Matthew is an oil painting by the Italian Baroque master Caravaggio that depicts the moment Jesus Christ calls on the tax collector Matthew to follow him. Commissioned for the Contarelli Chapel in the church of San Luigi dei Francesi in Rome, the work is celebrated for its dramatic use of light and shadow (chiaroscuro) and its naturalistic depiction of biblical figures in contemporary dress. It hangs alongside two other paintings of Matthew by Caravaggio: The Martyrdom of Saint Matthew and The Inspiration of Saint Matthew.

artworks.title: The Night Watch
artworks.description: The Night Watch, formally titled 'Militia Company of District II under the Command of Captain Frans Banninck Cocq', is a monumental group portrait by Dutch artist Rembrandt van Rijn. Painted in 1642, it depicts a city militia moving out, led by Captain Frans Banning Cocq and his lieutenant, Willem van Ruytenburch. Renowned for its dramatic use of light and shadow (tenebrism) and dynamic composition, the painting transforms a traditional civic guard portrait into a vibrant narrative scene. Despite its popular name, the scene takes place in daylight; the darkened appearance is due to the varnish and aging of the painting.

artworks.title: Las Meninas
artworks.description: Las Meninas is a 1656 painting by Diego Velázquez, the leading artist of the court of King Philip IV of Spain. The work is renowned for its complex and enigmatic composition, which blurs the boundaries between reality and illusion, artist and subject, and viewer and viewed. It depicts the young Infanta Margaret Theresa surrounded by her entourage in the artist's studio, with Velázquez himself shown painting, and the king and queen reflected in a mirror.

artworks.title: Ecstasy of Saint Teresa
artworks.description: The Ecstasy of Saint Teresa is a sculptural altarpiece group in white marble set in an elevated aedicule in the Cornaro Chapel of the church of Santa Maria della Vittoria in Rome. Designed and carved by Gian Lorenzo Bernini, the leading sculptor of his day, it depicts the mystical experience of Saint Teresa of Ávila as described in her autobiography, with an angel poised to pierce her heart with a golden arrow. Bernini also designed the elaborate setting of the chapel in marble, stucco, and paint, creating a theatrical effect.

artworks.title: Girl with a Pearl Earring
artworks.description: Girl with a Pearl Earring is an oil painting by Dutch Golden Age painter Johannes Vermeer, dated to around 1665. Sometimes referred to as the 'Mona Lisa of the North,' the painting depicts a young woman wearing an exotic dress, an oriental turban, and an improbably large pearl earring. The work is celebrated for its subtle use of light, intimate gaze, and enigmatic expression.

artworks.title: The Elevation of the Cross
artworks.description: The Elevation of the Cross is a monumental triptych painted by Peter Paul Rubens for the high altar of the Church of St. Walburga in Antwerp. The central panel depicts the dramatic moment of Christ's crucifixion, with muscular executioners raising the cross, while the side panels show mourners and Roman soldiers. The composition is celebrated for its dynamic movement, vivid emotion, and synthesis of Italian Renaissance and Flemish traditions.

artworks.title: The Swing
artworks.description: The Swing (French: L'Escarpolette) is a masterpiece of the Rococo period by French artist Jean-Honoré Fragonard. The painting depicts a young woman in a pink dress, joyfully swinging in a lush garden, while a hidden admirer looks up from the bushes and an older man pushes the swing. The work is celebrated for its playful eroticism, delicate brushwork, and exuberant use of color and light.

artworks.title: Apollo and Daphne
artworks.description: Apollo and Daphne is a life-size Baroque marble sculpture by Gian Lorenzo Bernini, depicting the climactic moment from Ovid's Metamorphoses when the nymph Daphne is transformed into a laurel tree to escape the god Apollo's pursuit.

artworks.title: The Anatomy Lesson of Dr. Nicolaes Tulp
artworks.description: The Anatomy Lesson of Dr. Nicolaes Tulp is a 1632 oil painting on canvas by Rembrandt, depicting Dr. Tulp demonstrating the musculature of the arm to members of the Amsterdam Guild of Surgeons. The work is celebrated for its dramatic composition, masterful use of light and shadow, and psychological depth.

artworks.title: Pilgrimage to Cythera
artworks.description: Pilgrimage to Cythera (also known as The Embarkation for Cythera) is a celebrated painting by French artist Jean-Antoine Watteau, depicting elegantly dressed couples departing for or returning from the mythical island of Cythera, the birthplace of Venus, symbolizing love and pleasure.

artworks.title: The Third of May 1808
artworks.description: The Third of May 1808, also known in Spanish as El tres de mayo de 1808 en Madrid or Los fusilamientos de la montaña del Príncipe Pío, is a painting completed in 1814 by Spanish artist Francisco Goya. The work commemorates the Spanish resistance to Napoleon's armies during the occupation of Madrid in 1808, at the beginning of the Peninsular War. It depicts the execution of Spanish rebels by French soldiers and is renowned for its emotional intensity and innovative composition. The painting, along with its companion piece The Second of May 1808, was commissioned by the provisional government of Spain after the expulsion of the French and the restoration of King Ferdinand VII.

artworks.title: Liberty Leading the People
artworks.description: Liberty Leading the People is a monumental Romantic painting by Eugène Delacroix commemorating the July Revolution of 1830 in France. The central allegorical figure, Liberty, personified as Marianne, leads a diverse group of revolutionaries over a barricade and the bodies of the fallen, holding the tricolor flag and a musket. The work is celebrated for its dynamic composition, emotional intensity, and political symbolism, encapsulating the spirit of revolution and the fight for freedom.

artworks.title: The Gleaners
artworks.description: The Gleaners is an oil painting by Jean-François Millet completed in 1857. It depicts three peasant women gleaning a field of stray grains of wheat after the harvest, highlighting the dignity and hardship of rural laborers.

artworks.title: Olympia
artworks.description: Olympia is a painting by French artist Édouard Manet depicting a nude woman reclining on a bed, attended by a maid. The work shocked audiences when first exhibited due to its frank portrayal of a nude courtesan and its modern, confrontational style.

artworks.title: Impression, Sunrise
artworks.description: Impression, Sunrise is an 1872 painting by Claude Monet, first exhibited at the 1874 exhibition that would become known as the first Impressionist exhibition in Paris. The painting depicts the port of Le Havre at sunrise and is credited with inspiring the name of the Impressionist movement.

artworks.title: Starry Night Over the Rhône
artworks.description: Starry Night Over the Rhône is one of Vincent van Gogh's celebrated nocturne paintings, depicting a star-filled sky reflected in the waters of the Rhône River in Arles, France. Painted outdoors at night, the work captures the interplay of artificial gas lighting along the riverbank and the natural brilliance of the stars, exemplifying van Gogh's fascination with the night and his innovative use of color and brushwork.

artworks.title: The Starry Night
artworks.description: The Starry Night is an oil-on-canvas painting by Dutch Post-Impressionist artist Vincent van Gogh, created in June 1889. It depicts a swirling night sky over a quiet town, as seen from the window of his asylum room at Saint-Rémy-de-Provence, with imaginative elements such as the cypress tree and a stylized village. The painting is celebrated for its expressive brushwork, vivid colors, and emotional intensity.

artworks.title: Bal du moulin de la Galette
artworks.description: Bal du moulin de la Galette is a celebrated Impressionist painting by Pierre-Auguste Renoir, depicting a lively outdoor scene of working-class Parisians dancing and socializing at the Moulin de la Galette in Montmartre, Paris.

artworks.title: The Thinker
artworks.description: The Thinker is a bronze sculpture by Auguste Rodin depicting a nude male figure of heroic size, seated on a rock with his chin resting on one hand as though deep in thought. Originally conceived as part of Rodin's monumental work 'The Gates of Hell', the figure has become an independent icon of intellectual activity and contemplation, symbolizing philosophy and the creative mind.

artworks.title: A Sunday Afternoon on the Island of La Grande Jatte
artworks.description: A Sunday Afternoon on the Island of La Grande Jatte is Georges Seurat's most celebrated painting, created between 1884 and 1886. This monumental work exemplifies the pointillist technique, in which small, distinct dots of color are applied in patterns to form an image. The scene depicts Parisians relaxing in a suburban park on the banks of the River Seine, capturing the leisure activities of late 19th-century society. The painting is a cornerstone of the Neo-Impressionist movement.

artworks.title: Les Demoiselles d'Avignon
artworks.description: Les Demoiselles d'Avignon is a groundbreaking large oil painting by Spanish artist Pablo Picasso, completed in 1907. The work depicts five nude female figures in a brothel on Carrer d'Avinyó in Barcelona, rendered with angular, fractured forms and mask-like faces. The painting marks a radical break from traditional composition and perspective, incorporating influences from Iberian sculpture and African masks. It is widely considered a pivotal work in the development of Cubism and modern art.

artworks.title: The Kiss
artworks.medium: Oil and gold leaf on canvas
artworks.description: The Kiss is an iconic painting by Austrian Symbolist painter Gustav Klimt, depicting a couple locked in an intimate embrace, their bodies entwined in elaborate, gilded robes against a shimmering gold background.

artworks.title: Composition VII
artworks.description: Composition VII is a monumental abstract oil painting created by Wassily Kandinsky in 1913. Widely regarded as one of his masterpieces, the work is a swirling, energetic composition that synthesizes themes of Resurrection, Judgment Day, the Flood, and the Garden of Eden. It exemplifies Kandinsky's pioneering role in the development of abstract art and his theories on the spiritual power of color and form.

artworks.title: Fountain
artworks.description: Fountain is a readymade sculpture by Marcel Duchamp consisting of a porcelain urinal signed 'R. Mutt'. Submitted to the 1917 Society of Independent Artists exhibition in New York, it challenged traditional notions of art by presenting an ordinary object as an artwork.

artworks.title: Guernica
artworks.description: Guernica is a monumental black-and-white oil painting by Pablo Picasso, created in response to the bombing of the Basque town of Guernica during the Spanish Civil War. The work powerfully depicts the tragedies of war and the suffering it inflicts upon individuals, particularly innocent civilians.

artworks.title: The Persistence of Memory
artworks.description: The Persistence of Memory is a 1931 painting by Spanish artist Salvador Dalí and is one of the most iconic works of Surrealism. The painting features melting pocket watches draped over a dreamlike landscape, evoking themes of time, memory, and the subconscious. Its enigmatic imagery and technical precision have made it a symbol of Surrealist art and a frequent reference in popular culture.

artworks.title: Broadway Boogie Woogie
artworks.description: Broadway Boogie Woogie is an abstract oil painting by Piet Mondrian, completed shortly after his move to New York City. The work reflects the city's grid structure and the rhythm of boogie-woogie music, using a vibrant arrangement of colored squares and rectangles.

artworks.title: The Red Studio
artworks.description: The Red Studio is an oil on canvas painting by French artist Henri Matisse, completed in 1911. The work depicts the artist’s studio in Issy-les-Moulineaux, filled with his own paintings, sculptures, and furniture, all unified by a vibrant red color that flattens the perspective and blurs the boundaries between objects and space.

artworks.title: Black Square
artworks.description: Black Square is a 1915 oil on canvas painting by Russian avant-garde artist Kazimir Malevich. It is considered the first and most iconic work of Suprematism, a movement focused on basic geometric forms and pure artistic feeling. Malevich created several versions of the painting, with the original debuting at the 0.10 Exhibition in Petrograd.

artworks.title: American Gothic
artworks.description: American Gothic is a 1930 oil painting on beaverboard by the American Regionalist artist Grant Wood. It depicts a stern-faced farmer holding a pitchfork beside a woman, often interpreted as his daughter, standing in front of a Carpenter Gothic-style house in rural Iowa. The painting has become an iconic image of American art, symbolizing rural values and the American Midwest.

artworks.title: Number 1A
artworks.medium: Oil and enamel paint on canvas
artworks.description: Number 1A is a large-scale abstract expressionist painting by Jackson Pollock, exemplifying his signature drip technique and energetic, gestural style.

artworks.title: Campbell's Soup Cans
artworks.description: Campbell's Soup Cans is a series of 32 paintings produced by American artist Andy Warhol. Each canvas depicts a different variety of Campbell's soup, rendered in a style that mimics commercial printing. The series is a landmark of the Pop Art movement, challenging traditional distinctions between fine art and mass-produced imagery.

artworks.title: Blue Poles
artworks.medium: Enamel and aluminum paint with glass on canvas
artworks.description: Blue Poles, also known as Number 11, 1952, is a landmark abstract expressionist painting by American artist Jackson Pollock. The work is renowned for its dynamic composition, featuring bold blue vertical lines over a complex web of dripped and splattered paint. Its acquisition by the National Gallery of Australia in 1973 was highly controversial and marked a turning point in the recognition of modern American art internationally.

artworks.title: Untitled (Portrait of Ross in L.A.)
artworks.description: "Untitled" (Portrait of Ross in L.A.) is a conceptual installation by Cuban-American artist Felix Gonzalez-Torres. The work consists of a pile of individually wrapped candies, ideally weighing 175 pounds (79 kg), which visitors are invited to take and consume. The diminishing pile alludes to the gradual loss of Gonzalez-Torres's partner, Ross Laycock, to AIDS, and the replenishment of the pile by museum staff symbolizes care and remembrance. The work is both participatory and ephemeral, challenging traditional notions of permanence in art.

artworks.title: The Physical Impossibility of Death in the Mind of Someone Living
artworks.medium: Tiger shark, glass, steel, 5% formaldehyde solution
artworks.description: The Physical Impossibility of Death in the Mind of Someone Living is a seminal work by Damien Hirst, consisting of a tiger shark preserved in formaldehyde within a large glass vitrine. Commissioned by art collector Charles Saatchi, the piece confronts viewers with the reality of death and the boundaries between art and life.

artworks.title: Balloon Dog
artworks.medium: Mirror-polished stainless steel with transparent color coating
artworks.description: Balloon Dog is a series of monumental sculptures by American artist Jeff Koons, created as part of his 'Celebration' series. The sculptures resemble twisted balloon animals, rendered in highly polished stainless steel with transparent color coatings. Five unique versions exist, each in a different color: blue, magenta, yellow, orange, and red.

artworks.title: The Dinner Party
artworks.description: The Dinner Party is a landmark installation artwork by American feminist artist Judy Chicago. The work consists of a large, triangular table with 39 elaborate place settings, each commemorating an important woman from history or mythology. The settings include intricately decorated ceramic plates and embroidered runners, with the names of 999 additional women inscribed on the floor below. The piece is a celebration of women's achievements and a critique of their historical marginalization.

artworks.title: Spiral Jetty
artworks.medium: Basalt rock, earth, salt crystals, mud
artworks.description: Spiral Jetty is a monumental earthwork and iconic piece of land art constructed by American artist Robert Smithson in April 1970. Built on the northeastern shore of the Great Salt Lake near Rozel Point in Utah, the work consists of a 1,500-foot-long (460 m), 15-foot-wide (4.6 m) counterclockwise spiral made from mud, salt crystals, basalt rocks, and earth. The sculpture interacts with the changing water levels and salinity of the lake, often submerging and re-emerging over time. Smithson documented the construction in a 32-minute color film, also titled Spiral Jetty.
artworks.creation_location: Rozel Point, Great Salt Lake, Utah, USA

artworks.title: Girl with Balloon
artworks.medium: Spray paint and stencil on wall
artworks.description: Girl with Balloon is a series of stencil murals created by the anonymous street artist Banksy, first appearing in London in 2002. The image depicts a young girl reaching out toward a red, heart-shaped balloon being carried away by the wind. Originally painted on the walls under Waterloo Bridge and in Shoreditch, the murals have become one of Banksy's most iconic images and have been reproduced in prints and other media.

artworks.title: The Weather Project
artworks.medium: Monofrequency lights, haze machines, mirrors, aluminum, scaffolding
artworks.description: The Weather Project is a large-scale installation by Icelandic–Danish artist Olafur Eliasson, which filled the Turbine Hall of Tate Modern in London. The installation simulated the experience of a vast indoor sun and mist-filled atmosphere, using light, mirrors, and haze to immerse visitors in an artificial environment that encouraged reflection on nature and perception.
